importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, indicating the current timeline of the federal government shutdown and the immediate urgency of the food stamp funding crisis.
The start date of the federal government shutdown, which has led to the depletion of funding for key food assistance programs like SNAP and WIC.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-week period before November benefits are set to run dry, during which the USDA warns that millions of Americans could lose access to food stamps due to lack of federal funding.

keyTakeAways: Roughly 42 million Americans are at risk of losing SNAP benefits in November due to the federal government shutdown.
The USDA has declared that SNAP funding will be depleted in two weeks if the shutdown continues, and has asked states to delay November payments until further notice.
The food stamp program (SNAP) provides an average monthly benefit of $188 per person and is a critical safety net for low-income families, especially as Thanksgiving approaches.
A $6 billion contingency fund exists, but it is insufficient to cover the $8 billion in projected November benefits.
New York Governor Kathy Hochul criticized the Trump administration for requiring states to halt new food stamp applications, calling it a deliberate action that harms vulnerable families.
The Trump administration previously used $300 million in tariff revenue to keep WIC operational, but this funding is not sufficient to support SNAP.
17 states have already stopped accepting new food stamp applications due to the inability to issue partial payments.
This is not the first time SNAP has faced funding issues during a shutdown; a similar situation occurred in 2018, when a workaround allowed payment continuation.
Advocacy groups and experts emphasize that the shutdown threatens food security and that urgent action is needed to protect vulnerable families.
The debate over SNAP funding reflects a broader political standoff between Republicans and Democrats over federal spending and policy priorities.

namedEntities.name: Brooke Rollins
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Agriculture Secretary under the Trump administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is the official who announced that food stamp funding will run out in two weeks, and criticized Democrats for prioritizing politics over food security.

namedEntities.name: Kathy Hochul
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly criticized the Trump administration for halting new food stamp applications, calling it a harmful and deliberate policy targeting vulnerable families.

namedEntities.name: US Department of Agriculture (USDA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal agency responsible for administering SNAP and WIC programs
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It has declared that SNAP benefits will be suspended in November due to funding shortfalls and has requested states to delay payments.

namedEntities.name: Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Formal name for food stamps, a major federal nutrition assistance program
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is at risk of shutting down in November, affecting millions of low-income Americans and creating a severe threat to food security during the Thanksgiving season.

namedEntities.name: WIC (Women, Infants, and Children program)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal food assistance program for pregnant women, new moms, and young children
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was temporarily protected by a $300 million tariff revenue infusion, but cannot be funded alongside SNAP due to lack of available funds.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. federal executive branch led by former President Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is at the center of the political dispute over funding, with officials like Rollins blaming Democrats and using tariff revenue to sustain certain programs.

namedEntities.name: Democrats
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political party opposing the Trump administration on spending issues
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They argue that Republicans refused to negotiate a spending deal that includes extended Obamacare subsidies, contributing to the shutdown and funding gaps.

namedEntities.name: Republicans
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Political party that has been accused of unwillingness to negotiate spending deals
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They are blamed by Democrats for blocking a spending deal, which contributed to the government shutdown and the current crisis in food assistance funding.

namedEntities.name: Obamacare premium subsidies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Funding mechanism tied to health insurance affordability under the Affordable Care Act
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Democrats argue that Republicans refused to extend these subsidies in a bipartisan spending deal, deepening the political divide and funding impasse.

namedEntities.name: Tariff revenue
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Funds generated from tariffs on imported goods
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration redirected $300 million in tariff revenue to keep WIC running, but not enough to support SNAP.

namedEntities.name: New York
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Governor Kathy Hochul of New York criticized the federal decision to halt new food stamp applications, highlighting state-level impacts of the policy.

namedEntities.name: Thanksgiving
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The upcoming holiday increases the urgency of food assistance, as vulnerable families face greater food insecurity during this critical time.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Amid a federal government shutdown that began on October 1, 2025, the U.S. Department of Agriculture has announced that the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), commonly known as food stamps, will run out of funds by early November. Approximately 42 million Americans are at risk of losing access to critical food assistance during this period. Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins attributed the funding shortfall to political disagreements, particularly blaming Democrats for prioritizing their agenda over food security. The program's $6 billion contingency fund is insufficient to cover the $8 billion needed for November benefits. While the Trump administration used $300 million in tariff revenue to sustain the WIC program, it lacks the funds to support SNAP. As a result, 17 states have suspended new food stamp applications, and advocacy groups warn that the shutdown endangers vulnerable families, especially as Thanksgiving approaches. The situation reflects a broader political standoff between Republicans and Democrats over federal spending and highlights the urgent need for action to protect basic food security.
title: Millions of Americans at Risk of Losing Food Stamps Amid Federal Shutdown
